results.title: Distinctively Australian
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Series presenter, Dr Susie Hanckel, leaves her city environment to examine what makes the ecosystems in our 400million year old country distinctively Australian. She looks at the adaptation of plants to the extremes of Australian climatic conditions - from the arid deserts and the snow covered eucalypts of the Australian Alps to the rainforests of North Queensland. This episode features distinguished scientist and specialist on Australia’s High Country, Alec Costain.

results.title: Living on a thin thread
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Paleobotanist Mary White explains the origins of the unique plant life of Australia, when it was part of the huge land mass, Gondwana, and the resulting evolution of plant life as it adapted to warmer conditions. Mary White challenged presenter Sue Hanckel to consider the earth as a complex balanced system, like the human body, with man, the virus, that threatens Earth’s very existence. Sue discovers a reaffirmation of Carl Jung’s observation that the future of our world hangs on a delicate thread.

results.title: Two in the bush: the Attic of the world
results.creator_credit: Christopher Parsons and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Two in the Bush”.
The naturalist, Gerald Durrell, observes Australian wild life. On a sheep farm he sees the problems kangaroos pose for farmers and meets some scientists doing field work on “roos”. He also sees the birth of a kangaroo, and its trip into its mother’s pouch. Research on the breeding biology of animals is also seen.

group_siblings.title: Koalas and lyre birds
group_siblings.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Koalas and lyre birds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Two in the Bush”.
The naturalist and author, Gerald Durrell, watches koala being caught and transferred from one reserve to another to save them from starvation. We also see lyrebirds in Sherbrooke Forest and visit a wild life sanctuary on the Gold Coast of Queensland.

results.title: World beaters
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TV Eye”.
This film looks behind the headlines of Japan’s economic miracle to the personal attitudes that make it possible. Also looks at the problems which lie ahead for Japan and the Japanese as the need to keep improving industrial performance puts pressure on the traditional concept of lifetime job security.

results.title: Elaine Dale: on mine own
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “TV Eye”.
This film is about the inspiring story of Elaine Dale, born without arms - as a result of a side effect of the drug Thalidomide - and now married with one child. Elaine speaks of her own personal struggle to live an independent life while her parents tell of their battle with the drug company for adequate compensation as well as the difficulties encountered in rearing Elaine.

group_works.title: A Wife among wives: notes on Turkana marriage

results.title: A Wife among wives: notes on Turkana marriage
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Turkana Conversations No. 2”.
This film examines how an African tribe, the Turkana, views marriage. Conversations amongst the community, particularly the women, are recorded and reveal a complex social structure.
